bioghist.p: Siegmund Lubin came from Germany to set up an optical shop in Philadelphia. He eventually designed improvements for cameras and projectors, and began to market his "Life Motion Pictures" in 1897. The Lubin Film Company became one of the most profitable of the new motion picture industry. In 1912 Lubin built a state of the art glassed in studio and factory at 20th and Indiana Streets. Lubin's logo and motto, "Clear As A Bell," referred to the superior quality of his motion picture images. The company went out of business in 1916.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of materials related to the the Lubin Film Company. Materials include: copies of printed Lubin Film Company Bulletins, 1913-1916; bound and unbound catalogs of films from 1905 and 1909; and seven scrapbooks (1911-1916) of newspaper and magazine clippings, playbills, advertisements, and flyers related to Lubin. The collection contains numerous photographs and a few negatives. Items include: film stills (8 x 10 and 5 x 7 black and white), candids, and portraits; images of the studio (20th & Indiana and Betzwood); group shots of cast members and crew; pictures of theaters owned by Lubin; several larger format photographs; and photos of Lubin and of his family. There are also a small number of glass lantern slides of titles, stills, and a series of lighting test images. Miscellaneous papers include: color lithograph flyers for Gods of Fate and The Great Divide; posters; clippings and articles about Lubin; a biographical sketch of Lubin by his daughter Emma Lubin Lowry; lists of films; and records related to research done on the collection. Artifacts in the collection include a 1905 projector, the hood ornament from Lubin's car, and a glass paperweight. The collection also includes film slides and negatives made by the Free Library.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
